content.description: Left hand starts down low on a pinch, the right starts on a triangular looking pinch a bit higher. The route moves up and to the left, never moving far off the ground as it follows the hill up the side of the boulder. EDIT: After figuring out a better beta for this route, I'd say it's toss up between a V5 and V6. Definitely more powerful and reachy than technical
content.protection: Pad. The only thing that really needs protecting is the part where you move over a small log that s holding back the earth. Other than that you can't really fall far enough to get hurt.
content.location: Southernmost part of the Southern boulder, starting right before the step someone built.

content.description:
Just a short problem I found after clearing out some vegetation. Start with both hands split. Move the left hand to match the right. And then go up with the right to a good single pad hold. Then the left can go to a good hold above that. After that itâ€™s just pulling yourself over the top and finding holds that feel comfortable up top.

Be careful as you step up top, I almost slipped and slid off the top.
content.location: Center of the Lenville Road Boulders.

content.description:
Start on the two juggy hands, with a fantastic foot out far left. Move right, make a big move up to a flake-ish jug, and top out. Good to warm up before working the harder problems in the area.

I'd never seen or heard of this problem before, I just saw it while going out to standoff. Feedback is appreciated for grade/name/any info.
content.protection: Pad, maybe a spotter for the topout. The flaky part on the right side is a little sketchy, best to try and grab it as far left as possible.
content.location: Starts in the middle of the boulder to the North. The first chalked holds you come across are the start hands.
